InfoText: After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ store a received-from element.
[ end the transaction.
<PgDn>
The received-from element identifies the person who requested the service.
The transaction code RF^ is used to input a received-from element,  as
follows:
RF^MRBRAUN
This entry indicates that Mr. Braun requested the service. Input this
entry. Note that the text does not include any spaces. If a space is input,
it will be deleted by the system. Input this entry.
The received-from element is displayed initially below the responsible
office identification code. However,  when the transaction is ended,  this
element is no longer displayed. Ignore the transaction.
Input the name^ entry^ for Mr. L. Schindler.
The abbreviation P^ or PAX^ may be used if the passenger requested his own"
reservation. This entry is input as follows:
RFP^
Input this entry.
The received-from element is free-format. Ignore the transaction.
Input the name entry for Mrs. P. Larsen.
Assume the passenger's assistant,  Mr. Svenson,  requested the reservation.
Input the received-from element.
Ignore the transaction.
Input the name entry for Mr. N. Patel.
Assume the passenger requested the reservation. Input the received-from entry.
Ignore the transaction.
Display neutral availability from on 22 June from FCO to AMS.

TerminalText: 3   AZ2058  Y4 L4 H4 T4 V4 Q4 K4  FCO D LIN   1300   1405   0*M82
InfoText: Sell 2 seats Y class on AZ 108.
The passengers are Mr. L. Tichwell and Mrs. P. Tichwell. Input the
passenger names.
Now input the Copenhagen home phone 45 31268765.
Arrange ticketing for 19 June.
The reservation was received from Mr. Tichwell. Input the received-from
element.
This PNR now includes a received-from element,  name elements,  an itinerary,
a contact element,  and a ticketing element. In the next lesson,  you will
learn how to end the transaction and store the reservation. Ignore the
the transaction.
You have reached the end of the lesson. Repeat this lesson until
you can finish without requesting help.
